text: Nicole, early 30's, appears out of the dark.
She makes people feel comfortable about even embarrassing things. We remain CLOSE on her face in shadow. She’s very still and very serious.
She really listens when someone is talking...

head_text.subj: EXT. FLATBUSH AVENUE, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY

text: Her coming out of a subway. A young “funny” ASPCA solicitor stops her.
Hey, you look like you care about animals?
I do. --.sometimes she listens TOO much, for too long-- She’s a good citizen. The kid launches into his pitch. She listens intently and starts writing down her phone number.
She always knows the right thing to do when it comes to difficult family shit.

head_text.subj: INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. DAY

text: Charlie is sulking. A hand holds out a phone.
Just call him.
No.
Call him. No.
(with real empathy) Call him. He reluctantly grabs the phone.

I get stuck in my ways and she knows when to push me and when to leave me alone. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY She cuts their son, (8 years old) Henry’s hair. We see Charlie sweeping up.
She cuts all our hair. Cuts Charlie’s hair. We see the kid sweeping up. Cuts her own in the mirror. Charlie and the kid play in the background. She sweeps up her own hair.
She’s always inexplicably brewing a cup of tea that she doesn’t drink.

head_text.subj: INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE'S APARTMENT. SEVERAL DAYS

text: A kettle whistles. STILL LIFES of mugs of tea on window sills, bookshelves, Henry’s toy shelf, on the floor... All the kitchen cabinets are open. Charlie closing drawers, picking up shoes. Charlie hitting his head on th corner of an open cabinet.

And it’s not easy for her to put away a sock, or close a cabinet, or do a dish, but she tries for me. A framed PHOTO of Nicole, Sandra (her mom) and Cassie (he sister) standing in the front lawn of a Hollywood home. Nicole is pretending to step on the reclining dog.

Nicole grew up in LA around actors and directors and movies and TV and is very close to her mother, Sandra, and, Cassie, her sister. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Charlie rips open a present. It’s a trumpet.
Nicole gives great presents. She is a mother who plays -- really plays -- she never steps off playing or says it’s too much (and it must be too much some of the time).
She and Henry play in the park with Star Wars figures. Th kid makes high pitched sounds for the fights.
Arrrh, waaa, urgh...
Arrgh-- No, he’s dead.
My guy is dead?
He’s dead but you can use this guy.
(taking that guy) She’s competitive. Arrrhhggg-- INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Nicole, Charlie and Henry are playing Monopoly.
Goddammit! I was just IN jail! Henry and Charlie look at each other and laugh.
Do NOT laugh at me. I’m serious. Do NOT LAUGH AT ME!  INT. HENRY’S ROOM. ANOTHER NIGHT Nicole is reading to Henry in bed. She’s falling asleep while reading, but still managing to read.
She’s a great dancer. Infectious. She makes me wish I could dance.
Nicole putting on a song and getting people to dance at a cast party.

She always says when she doesn’t know something or hasn’t read a book or seen a film or a play (whereas I fake it or say something like, “I haven’t seen it in a while.”) She keeps the fridge over-full. No one is ever hungry in our house. She can drive a stick. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S KITCHEN. ANOTHER DAY Charlie’s trying to open a jar of pickles. He struggles. He knocks it on a table. Grabs a dish towel and tries it that way. No luck.

She’s amazing at opening jars because of her strong arms, which I’ve always found very sexy. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY On TV, a younger Nicole (acting in a movie) is part of a raucous college party.
You might as well get what you paid for! She grabs her shirt and lifts it-- We PAUSE mid-lift before it comes off.
She’s brave. After that movie, All Over The Girl, she could have stayed in LA and been a movie star, but she gave that up to do theater with me in New York.
We're back to the first image of her face in half-shadow. Suddenly she walks forward and into a spotlight.
My crazy ideas are her favorite things to figure out how to execute. She walks across the floor and climbs (scales like a rock face) the body of a male actor.
Try it crawling but also standing. We see that she’s on a stage, rehearsing for a play.
She’s my favorite actress.
CLOSE on Charlie, early 30’s, in deep thought. A warm yellow glow on his face.
What I love about Charlie... Charlie is undaunted. He never lets other people’s opinions or any set-backs keep him from what he wants to do.

head_text.subj: INT. PIZZERIA, PARK SLOPE, BROOKLYN. DAY

text: Charlie eats sloppily with Henry at a pizza place. He suddenly stands up and walks around to Henry’s side. He asks Henry to raise his arms. He lifts Henry’s sweater up over his arms and turns it around to face the right way.

Charlie eats like he’s trying to get it over with and like there won’t be enough food for everyone. A sandwich is to be strangled while devoured. But he’s incredibly neat and I rely on him to keep things in order. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. LATE DAY Nicole is reading in a room. All the lights go out. She looks up. Charlie is at the switch.
Sorry.
He’s energy conscious. He turns them back on.
He doesn’t look in the mirror too often. He cries easily in movies.
He and Henry exit a movie theater. Both of them are crying.
I cried four times.
Me too. I wonder if it was the same four.

He is very self-sufficient -- he can darn a sock and cook himself dinner and iron a shirt. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S KITCHEN. EVE He’s cooking - it’s elaborate. There are a lot of pots, a lot of steam. Henry is “helping.”
(holding up a knife) The peppers are cut!
He rarely gets defeated (which I feel like I always do). INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. ANOTHER DAY Nicole is raging about something.
Charlie takes all of my moods steadily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dresser, he never looks embarrassing which is hard for a man.
Charlie is serving in a tennis game.
He’s very competitive. He double faults.
(to himself) Goddammit Charlie! Get it together. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S BEDROOM. NIGHT Henry walks into their bedroom and taps Charlie on the shoulder until he wakes up.
(whispers) I had a bad dream.

He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night. INT. HENRY’S ROOM. SAME He puts Henry back to sleep. Henry doesn’t want to sleep. They compromise with Charlie sleeping on the floor. Then Henry climbing down and sleeping with him on the floor. Then Charlie slipping out and getting into the bed. Then the kid getting into the bed with him.
It’s almost annoying how much he likes it, but then it’s mostly nice.
He and Henry reading on the subway. The doors close. The train lurches forward. Charlie looks up suddenly.
He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way.
Shit!
What’s “shit?”
That was our stop!

He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad. Nicole, from across a table picks something from between her teeth, she looks back up at Charlie who is off-camera and smiles. It’s still there. She starts digging for it again.

Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was a lot of alcohol and some violence in his childhood. Henry plays on the floor. Charlie leads a meeting with hi set decorator and Nicole and the stage manager around a b table. They reference a model of the stage set.
He moved to New York from Indiana with no safety net and now he’s more a New Yorker than any New Yorker.
Charlie is passing out coffees to all the actors and crew members of their theater at the beginning of a rehearsal. He’s gotten everyone’s drink right, and bought them all himself.
He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around.

I made sure they used the With the theatre company he right almond milk-- cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant. He could remember all the inside jokes.
(handing an intern a coffee) And where do YOU go when it’s windy?!
(laughing, flattered, remembering) Oh yeah, that was funny!

We RETURN to the close-up of Charlie. He sits in the back of an empty theater taking notes, the small yellow readin light illuminating his face. He watches Nicole, in rehearsal, climb up onto the actor as she did earlier.

Let’s stop there. Nicole, up almost atop the actor’s head, turns to him wit a look that asks, “Was that OK?” Charlie nods. INT. MEDIATOR’S OFFICE. DAY CLOSE on a sheet of paper: We can see written everything just heard.
Who wants to start? Nicole, no make-up, in a baggy sweatshirt and jeans, sits in a chair, not saying a word, staring at a piece of pape in her lap.
I’m not going to read this out loud.
Why is that?

I don’t like what I wrote.  10. We see now that she and Charlie are sitting in two adjace chairs in an office on the Upper West Side. A male mediator, 50's, in a sweater vest wearing too many rings, tightly cross-legged, facing them.

As we mediate your separation and eventual divorce, things can become quite contentious, so I like to begin with a note of positivity. For the people I work with to remember why they got married in the first place. And so, that as you come apart, you’re reminded that this is a person you had great feeling for and maybe still do in many ways--
(holding up his phone) I‘1l read mine. I like what I wrote.
For it to really work, you both have to read--
(folding up her paper) I’m not going to.
OK-- She always says I can’t write. But I think mine is pretty good.
Nicole, maybe you'll change your mind once you hear Charlie's.
(looking at him now) I don’t want to hear Charlie’s.
We promised to listen.
That’s right, that’s the very first step in this process. Nicole stands up, suddenly furious.  11.
Well, I think I’1l go if you two are just going to sit around and suck each other’s dicks! A hubbub of protests then:

Audience members watch, rapt. Nicole is on-stage in a red dress. A black and white video of her face projected on either side of her. On stage, she delivers her lines in a almost life-less way while the video Nicole is very animated and emotional. Charlie sits in the back of the theatre--she can’t see hi face, but she knows where he is. She continues speaking, looking into the audience when several bodies approach her, turn her to her side and car her off like a stiff rolled-up rug. Charlie sees her looking and is sad and disturbed and sto writing his notes for a moment. Behind her, a portal opens up, the stage is awash in red light and the company members carry her through the door.

Closing night party. The whole company is there celebrating, this is clearly their spot. There’s a piano, and names are pulled from a bowl and people take turns singing. Investors mingle as well, notable for the disobedient air of people who shouldn’t be “downtown.” A woman, 30’s, Mary Ann, also the stage manager (we saw h earlier in rehearsals), sits in a booth with the costume designer, Donna, 40’s. She looks over at Charlie ina booth in the corner, surrounded by members of the troupe. He works on a beer and makes more notes in a book.
Do you think I can go over there now? Donna, turns and we SWING OVER to: Nicole, on the other side of the room at a table flanked by other members of t cast and crew.
Not yet.  12. On Charlie’s end of the room, Frank, an older actor, carries on with Terry, a younger one.
...Charlie gave me the note - but it’s really for you: he told me to pick up my cues.
How is that for me?
Acting is reacting - I’m responding to you and you’re slowing ME down.
..-hey, hello, Frank - it’s closing night, you know, we’re done?!
...first, no, we're moving (also doing HANDS!) to To The BroadWAY! (doing some HANDS!) The BroadWAY-
The Main Stem. They all cheers and laugh.
..-but we’ll have to restage .-..it’s still a good note.. it anyway!
.».-and you know Charlie, it’s never done, he never finishes.
We NEVER FINISH!
Love you, Charlie. They all laugh, but they’re excited, it’s big. Charlie, still looking at his notes, reaches out and pats the actor’s leg affectionately. Terry, gets up--
I need a cigarette.  13. --and makes his way across the room passing other company members and snippets of conversation.
(dramatically) ...that’s why it seems wrong to take over for Nicole - the role is hers! And what if her pilot doesn’t go, she’ll come back from LA and want the part back, right?
No, she’s done with it. Something like 100 percent of pilots don’t get picked up.
It can’t be 100 percent. There would never be any shows.
No, but statistically, it’s You don’t think Charlie and true. The probability is Nicole will ever get back zero. It’s one of those together? things.
(sadly) No, this time it’s really over.
(to herself) Still feels weird...
..-I feel like MY parents It’s always been “Charlie are splitting up. and Nicole.” It just doesn’t sound right any other way.
Poor Henry. Terry passes Mary Ann and Donna who still watch Charlie.
(re: Charlie) How about now?
I'd wait, honey. Terry arrives at the booth at the other end of the room where Nicole and her group are camped together.  14.
(shaking her head) He still giving notes?
Yep.

(to Nicole) You’re lucky, Nic, I wish I was going to LA. You can have space in LA. There’s no SPACE here. Nicole looks across the restaurant and catches Charlie’s eye. He mouths “hi” and she nods. Is it nice?
(growing more impatient) Now?

Don’t do it. Frank stands and makes a toast to Charlie and Nicole and the move to Broadway ("The Main Stem”) and how much they’ miss Nicole and then makes it about him returning to Broadway with the young turks. In 1968, he was the young turk.

Winning your first Tony at 27-- which I did--messes with your head. I was just a baby! Elia Kazan came backstage on opening night elbowing Mike Nichols into a corner. Mike, who I later turned down twice, a big regret of mine... During the speech, Mary Ann, the stage manager, suddenly rises (we can see Donna making protestations) and makes h approach to Charlie’s corner, whispering something in his ear.

I wanted to make sure that I have all your notes down so I can compile them into the master list for when we move into the new theater... Nicole, clocking this, abruptly stands. Charlie sees her rise and does the same.  15.

Riding home across the Manhattan Bridge. Nicole sits on the mostly empty bench gazing out the window. Although there are available seats, Charlie stands and leans against the doors. INT. CHARLIE AND NICOLE’S APARTMENT. NIGHT She and Charlie enter and relieve a young babysitter who for some reason is buttoning her pants up and looks a little ashamed.
Oh hey, I didn’t expect you guys until late.
How’s he doing?

Good, good. He went to bed on time, no fuss. I read him some of Cricket in Times Square... (takes them in) God, you guys are so attractive. (hand to mouth) Shit, sorry. I didn’t stop that from being said. Nicole goes back and checks on Henry--

Ha! No it’s okay. I’1l pay Hey, thanks! And also the you for the whole time, we travel time to Greenpoint-- decided to come home early. She stumbles on something. It’s his little suitcase, open on the floor--toys crammed into it. He’s sleeping soundly all twisted up in his superhero sheets. He uses a well- worn white bear as a pillow. She fixes his sheets. The Babysitter is gone and Charlie is setting up the couc as his bed. He surveys the room while he reflexively fiddles with a small X-Acto knife on his key chain. We CU QUICKLY between objects (the clicking sound of the knife a soundtrack): Books, a chair, table, lamp, a TV which turns on, painting, photos... Objects from their life together. (Mugs of tea rest beside some of these objects. A book on a table.  16. Nicole retrieves the book and heads back to the bedroom. Charlie’s voice stops her:
It’s not always going to be like this, it’s going to get better. Nicole nods.
If you don’t like that mediator, we'll find another one--
Yeah... We might not need a mediator, we'll just split everything anyway, I don’t care--
Me neither-- You can have most of it.
We'll get apartments near Right. each other, make it easier for Henry--
We'll figure it out. We want the same things. Nicole meets Charlie’s eye. He hesitates.
In the meantime, the pilot will be fun for you.
You don’t think it’s bad, do you?
(hesitates) I don’t ever watch TV so, you know, I can’t tell... Nicole glances over at the TV which is on.
Uh huh.
I told Henry I’11l come out to LA in two weeks to see him.  17. Nicole nods. Charlie looks down at his notebook. Looks back up at Nicole.
Yes?
Nothing. Nicole turns, and then turns back.
I can tell you want to give me a note.
No, I don’t... Yeah, I mean, yes I do. But I guess, I guess it doesn’t matter now. You won’t be with the show anymore. It’s stupid.
(knowing him well) You’re not going to be able to go to sleep until you tell me.
Maybe not.
Okay then.
Well, yes, okay, but just because saying it out loud might help me remember it for later.
Sure.
(reading) --okay-- So - there were two things - I thought your posture at the top of scene seven was still too dignified...
--and then at the end, I could tell that you were pushing for the emotion--  18.
--you know I can’t cry on stage and I know you don’t like when I fake it, but I thought maybe it would come tonight. But it didn’t... He flips through the notebook. Silence.
That’s all I had. Thanks for indulging me.

Goodnight Charlie. She starts crying as soon as she turns away from him. We MOVE with her as she cries through the apartment to their bedroom. She trips briefly on one of her suitcases also lying on the floor open and half-packed. She removes her shoes, but not her clothes, and gets into bed, crying. Fade to Black. A curtain flies open revealing a rich blue sky and swayin palm trees. The light is painfully bright. We hear a female voice lightly singing:

“This is the day, this is the day...” INT. NICOLE’S CHILDHOOD BEDROOM, LOS ANGELES. MORNING Nicole opens her eyes which are crusted with mascara and tears. Her mother, Sandra, 60’s, violently opens the curtains, loudly closes drawers and doors. We're in LA.
(singing) “That the Lord has made, that the Lord has made...” Nicole rolls over. Henry, yawning, lies next to her in th bed.

(singing) “Let us rejoice, let us rejoice. And be glad in it and be glad in it...”  19. This is her childhood bedroom in her mom’s house. There are old magazines (Cosmo, Seventeen, Teen Vogue, Maxim) with photos of Nicole. An MTV Best Kiss award. There is “Teenage Nicole” and “Adult Nicole” all mashed up togethe and both Nicole’s are messy. Nicole presses her face into the pillow.
Mom... (tired) G-ma summer is for relaxing.
(to Henry) You can’t make home too nice, otherwise your children will never leave-- Nicole whispers to Henry.
What do you want to do today?
Hang out and relax with you. (nuzzling him) Me too.
(listening in) No relaxing! Nicole has a hair and make-up test and Henry, we got you into Fairy Camp with the cousins.
I hate Fairy Camp.
Cassie says everyone likes Fairy Camp and I think this is true. Sandra kisses Henry on the head.
Henry, go make your mom some coffee like I taught you--
Mom, wait till you taste my coffee. Henry walks off, hair sticking up. Sandra fluffs the pillows, retrieving Henry’s white bear.  20.
Do you always sleep together? Even in New York?
It’s just for now, while we go through this transition. Shit, don’t tell Charlie when he gets here -- he hates co-sleeping. Nicole climbs out of bed. Her pillow is stained with blac eye make-up.
Well, I have to say, I agree with Charlie.
Surprise, surprise. Nicole walks toward the bathroom, Sandra behind her--
It’s as if you’ve exploded (looking at her phone) into this room. Jesus, it’s early. --and into the bathroom, her mother follows her inside.
I can do this part alone?
That’s fine. I won’t look. Sandra leans against the sink, Nicole shrugs and lets her how can she stop her now?
As long as you’re in my house, wake up is at 6:30 AM. And until you know what you want to do, we're going to do what I like to do.
I can’t just go from what Charlie wanted to do to what you want to do. Nicole finishes, flushes and starts washing her hands.  21.

Even though I’m sixty-four and have a dead gay husband, I manage to get up everyday and live my life and feel pretty good about myself so maybe your Mom knows a thing or two. Nicole heads out of the room and down the main staircase. Her mom following her, of course.
You know what I would do? (no idea) About what?
When Charlie gets here, I would whisk him off to Palm Springs? That’s what your father and I did whenever we hit a speed bump--
Didn’t you walk in on Dad And I always regretted blowing the porter in Palm getting so upset about it. Springs?
Charlie and I are getting a divorce, Mom. There’s nothing for us in Palm Springs.
(suddenly angry)

head_text.subj: YOU NEED TO WASH YOUR FACE BEFORE

text: They both enter the kitchen. Henry has made a giant mess with the coffee, and he’s trying to press down on a Frenc Press coffee maker.
When Daddy gets here maybe we can all go on the Jaws ride--
Yeah-- (accommodating) Or I can go once with you and once with Daddy because I wouldn’t mind going twice anyway--  22.
(to Henry) No, we'll all go together, Did you know Universal sweetheart. Studios is where I did my first screen test-- Henry presents his mom a cup of coffee.
On the plane, I re-read the pilot as if I were Charlie reading it and I started to think it’s just bad.
My agent says it’s “one to watch.” She sips her coffee.
(to Henry) This coffee IS good. Thank you. (to Sandra) What if Charlie’s on Broadway with the play I brought him--which I originated and I’m just doing bad TV.
It doesn’t matter. Everyone is only impressed when they see someone on TV.

She’s beautiful. Nicole is standing in front of a camera in a hair/makeup/wardrobe test. She’s barefoot in a nightgown with some kind of red mask being applied to her face. We hear voices (that she can’t) murmuring near the monitor. Nicole holds what looks like a blue, foam football and stares combatively at the camera. Hands enter frame, adjusting her hair, swapping out the masks.
Where’s she been for the past ten years?
Doing weird theater in New She looks great. York.  23.
Can I say something? No one answers. We hear bits of side-conversations about book club book they’re all reading.
Downtown shit. I saw one. It rained on stage.
Plays make me uncomfortable. It was good. Edgy. Directed by her husband. Supposedly very controlling.
The live aspect-- We’re lucky to have her.
I’m surprised she said yes. We can thank her divorce.
Can she move her hand? It’s going to be hard to roto the hair in on the baby around her fingers--
(aloud to Nicole) Can you move your hand further down the baby?
What do you mean? Like down here?
Off his head entirely-- I’d need to support his head.
No, no, support the head, of course, just try to do it from the shoulders? She hesitantly slides her hand down the blue football.
Perfect.
I can’t hold a baby like this.
She’s right, that’s going to look weird. A handsome, bearded and tatted 24.
Just so you know, we can TOTALLY do it, it’s just going to take time and money and mean less hair. grip, 30's, Pablo, enters frame with a white bounce board, holding it up to her.
So we can see your pretty face. And not ours.
Ha. You should have seen me before the plants invaded.
I say that with respect. I was raised by two mothers.
(not amused) Can you lower the board please, Pablo? The grip lowers the bounce board then raises it directly front of Nicole’s face, then lowers it, being cute.
Here? How Nicole smiles. A hand removes another.
How about now? Pablo finally places the board
(to the DP off-camera) That better, boss? Someone walks through the shot arm.
(louder) Can I say something? ‘bout here? her mask and applies
Why is there always a flirty grip. in the proper position.
I can do ANYTHING you want, but we’ll need to have her two hours before call every day we work with the plants-- carrying an enormous plant
Hold on. (to Nicole) What honey?  25.
She has to know how to hold a baby. Later after she kills Donny, she becomes this sort of earth mother for the plant community and that won’t make sense if we think she’s a bad mother to her own kid.
She kills Donny? That’s a secret. We didn’t give the crew those pages.
You don’t want her to appear unsympathetic this early in the show, do you?
Does Donny know? She’s right.
Also, why does she kill Donny anyway?

Nicole marches across the soundstage, still in the nightgown, now wearing Uggs, followed by the male (Dennis and female (Carol) producers, both 50’s. He wears all denim. She’s in fitted jeans, and a white blazer. There’s also a cadre of hair and make-up and wardrobe people.
Must be nice to get out of New York. Our daughter, Mia is at NYU living in a shoe box--
Well, I’m from out here-- She's says it went up toa hundred and four the other day--
We're just so excited to (nods ) have you. I’m excited to be here --
We're going for an early aughts aesthetic — so having your presence nails that.
What signifies early aughts?  26. They go outside, the bright LA light hitting their eyes. Everyone puts on sunglasses.
Into The Girl was on TV--
(correcting her) --or streaming or something All Over-- and you are fucking HOT in that movie.
Carol-- Fuck it, I speak my mind!
We're not allowing our son to see it.
Because you show your tits.
Carol-- Yeah.
This is Carter Mitchum, he’s a futurist at UCLA who’s consulting on all the environmental stuff for the show. Carter, 30’s, has been politely following behind. He reaches forward to shake her hand.
You know, so it’s accurate.
Nice to meet you. So, is it?
What? Accurate?
So far none of it. Nicole laughs. She’s handed another nightgown by the wardrobe assistant. “For when you’re on the mother ship.”
This pilot WILL go. Get ready to move back to LA!  27.
And listen: everything you were saying back there was absolutely right--
Except no one knows we’re If she’s a bad mom, we'll killing Donny. Including lose the audience. Donny.
Oh...good, you know, I just thought-
Let us know if you’d like to be part of our writer’s room -- I bet you'd be really helpful.
(surprises herself even) Or I could direct? Sorry, maybe that sounds crazy.
No, yeah... Do you have a reel?
No, because I’ve never done it. I mean, I watched my husband do it for years... (quietly) Almost ex-husband? What’s the opposite of fiance?
(taking her in) We'll talk to your agents about it.

At our theater, I always wanted to direct and Charlie would say something like “The next one!” But he was always the director and there never was a next one. (contradicting herself) But I don’t know, maybe there would have been if we stayed married. You know, I don’t know. Nicole turns away, embarrassed. The Female Producer has been watching her, while the Male Producer is just textin like a motherfucker.  28. INT. NICOLE’S TRAILER Nicole enters the cramped space and realizes the Female Producer is right behind her. Nicole tries to busy herself.
(takes out her phone) I’m going to give you a number.
Oh...OK. Is it a therapist? I have a therapist. Well, she’s my mom’s therapist. We share her.
She’s a lawyer, she represented me when I left Dennis.
(re: the male producer) Since 2013. You and Dennis are divorced?
And you still work together? That’s nice.
Oh, no, he’s a fucking cocksucker. Nora got me half of this project in the settlement.
We talked about doing it without lawyers.
You think that, but you My sister made me meet a won't... bunch of them already, I just HATED them.
(with certitude) Call Nora. She saved my life.

I’m sorry I look so schleppy. INT. NORA FANSHAW’S OFFICE. DAY Nora Fanshaw, 40's, looks amazing and elegant. Today she is in tight designer jeans, a YSL blazer, red pumps and full make-up.  29. Nicole, in old jeans and a button-down, sits on a comfortable, stylish couch, a Moroccan rug on the floor-- an office that looks like a suite at a W Hotel. A sheepskin throw, fresh flowers on the coffee table.
I had an event at my kid’s school. Nicole grows suddenly self-conscious about what she’s wearing.
Let me get this out of the way, I think you’re a wonderful actress.
Thank you.
I loved All Over The Girl but the theater stuff too.
(can’t help but be I saw Electra. pleased) You’ve seen the theater stuff?
I was in New York last year for my book -- which, remind me to give you a copy -- and my publisher took me.
Oh...great. Thank you. Fantastic. You’re awesome.
(almost apologetically) Charlie directed it.
I know. He’s very talented.
He is. They’re moving it to Broadway. Without me of course.

I was demonstrating as part of a Grandmothers for Peace rally. I was with my mom, but she didn’t go to jail. (MORE )
with? OK. 127.
(laughs, remembering) Somehow she avoided that part. But I did.
Do you use drugs or alcohol?
I drink alcohol.
How much alcohol do you drink?
I don’t know. Glass of wine with dinner. Sometimes more?
How much more?
Well, sometimes, a few... I sometimes split a bottle of wine with someone?
Who do you split it I mean, if I’m having dinner with someone and we order a bottle of wine.
You know, like if you’re at a restaurant and you say, “Should we go by the glass or get a bottle?”
You get a bottle.
Sometimes! Sometimes I go by the glass. You know, it depends... (hesitates) Do you mean drugs ever? I have done drugs. In college. I don’t do it regularly.
Anything since you've been a mother?
Pot a few times. Coke once at a party. But Henry wasn’t with me.  Silence. 128.
What would you say are your strengths as a parent?

I listen. I play. I put in the time. I love taking care of him, watching him grow up... Sometimes it’s true what they say about it goes so fast, but sometimes it’s not. Sometimes it goes too slow, honestly...
What are your weaknesses?
I’m too precise. I care too much.
Are those weaknesses?
(smiles) Maybe not. (thinks) You know what, he can be an asshole and I can get really pissed off. I/’11 call him on being an asshole and--
I’m going to stop you there. Nora stands up from behind the female associate who is doing the practice interview with Nicole. We’re in Nora’s office.

Don’t ever say that. People don’t accept a mother who drinks too much wine and yells at her child and calls him an asshole. I get it. I do it too. While she talks she also texts and addresses emails on he phone.  129.

We can accept an imperfect Dad. Let’s face it, the idea of a good father was only invented like 30 years ago. Before that fathers were expected to be silent and absent and unreliable and selfish and we can all say that we want them to be different but on some basic level we ACCEPT them, we LOVE them for their fallibilities. But people absolutely DON’T accept those same failings in mothers. (building up steam) We don't accept it structurally and we don't accept it spiritually because the basis of our Judeo- Christian Whatever is Mary Mother of Jesus and she’s PERFECT. She’s a virgin who gives birth, unwaveringly supports her child, and holds his dead body when he’s gone. But the Dad isn’t there. He didn’t even do the fucking because God’s in heaven. God is the father and God didn't show up so you have to be perfect and Charlie can be a fuck up and it doesn't matter. You’1ll always be held to a different, higher standard and it’s FUCKED up, but that’s the way it is.

Charlie is cooking an elaborate dinner. The bell rings. He takes a deep breath. He glances into Henry’s room. He’s playing by himself on the floor. He walks through the set-decorated living room which look relatively homey, full of warmth and board games and pictures of Charlie and Henry. Charlie opens the door. A diminutive woman with frizzy hair is staring at the door across the hall. She startles turns around and smiles and puts out her hand.
I think I rang the wrong bell. Nancy Katz.  130.
(shaking) Hi, I’m Charlie Barber. Nancy, can I get you anything?

Oh, I’m easy. A glass of water? Kitchen. Charlie opens up a cabinet. Plates. He opens another cabinet. Pots. A third cabinet. Empty. Finally he finds glasses in a low cupboard. He glances back at th evaluator who waits patiently.
It’s a new apartment. Charlie and Nancy take their drinks to the dining room table.
Shall we go in here?
Sure. What’s a day like for the two of you here?
Well, if he has school, I take him there, of course and pick him up, assuming I can do both.
What prevents you from picking him up?
Um, you know, work. I’m preparing a play I’m directing in a few months.
Oh, what is that?
Kasimir and Karoline by Odon von Horvath? We’re doing it at the Barrow in New York.
So, you have to be away?  131.
Yes. Recently, since Nicole has been working on this show in LA, I come back and forth a lot.
That sounds difficult.
It is. And expensive. I’11 try to take him with me some of the time, but Nicole doesn’t like for him to fly so much.
That can be hard on a child. All that recycled air.
(hesitates) Well, he’s sturdy.
Some parents won't take their kids to a restaurant because of these super bugs.
Uh huh. (looking at her notes) I notice on one visit to Los Angeles, you came on a Sunday and left ona Thursday. Why not stay for a weekend?
Oh...on that time, I had tech for Electra back in New York.
What’s that?
It was my Broadway debut. I don’t know what tech is.
It’s the technical part of the production. You figure out the lights and--
(moving forward) (still explaining) And what's a weekend day Monday is our day off in like? theater--  132.

(discovering his mouth is dry) Well, out here he has basketball on Saturday at 12, 11, I’m sorry and so we go there. (swallowing) And then afterwards, maybe we’1ll get lunch somewhere and then if there’s a movie to see...
Does he like basketball?
He does. His coach, um, Rick says he’s a good dribbler and I’ve seen that...
Uh huh.
Ron. I’m sorry. His coach’s name is Ron. Rick’s his dentist in New York. The evaluator writes something in her book.
Well, you know our home home was...is in New York. That’s where we live and--
New York is a long way from here.
We like it because we can walk.
You can walk here.
Not really.
And the space. Charlie nods. CUT TO: HENRY’S ROOM Henry plays on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair.  133.
Do you like your school?
I love it.
What's your favorite part about it?
I don’t know. Maybe gym.
You like math--
Math is boring. Charlie enters and hands Henry a plate with cut-up apple. Henry takes it.
Thanks.
You’re welcome. But you’re getting really good at it.
No.
Well, you are, but... Charlie exits.
What do you and your Dad like to do together?
When I’m at my Dad’s we sometimes watch a movie or build a Lego or something. My Dad’s a great Lego builder. Nancy smiles.
Charlie listening at the door, smiles.  134.
And at your mom’s?
At home, I have most of my toys and- Charlie bristles at the word “home” used to describe Nicole's. HENRY’S ROOM

--there’s a pool and I have a tree- house and jungle gym. We play lots of games. We have Super Secret Treasure Hunt which is really fun. Cut TO: KITCHEN Charlie is making ground meat and potatoes and spinach. H has a lot of burners going at once, making a mess.
Sweetheart, do you want to help me set the table.
Do I have to?
Just come in here and grab a plate and--
I’m playing.
Henry! HENRY’S ROOM Henry plays with his men on the floor. The evaluator sits in a chair nearby.
(grudgingly) O-K. Henry gets off his chair and goes into--
Why are you being like this?
What?
If I ask you to help out, help out.
(eating something from the pan) What is this?
It’s special meal.
What are the green things? There aren’t green things in special meal.
It’s just a garnish.
Here, I’1ll take it off.
I don’t want to eat anything it touched.
It doesn’t change the taste of anything.
I might want to be a vegetarian. Mom's a vegetarian.
Is she a vegetarian now?
Yeah.
(prickly) Well, then you should like garnish. It’s all garnish, vegetarianism.  136. Charlie looks over. Nancy stands, watching, in the threshold of the kitchen.
I’m done with my water. She returns her water to the sink.
Charlie and Henry eat. Nancy sits with them.
You sure you don’t want anything?
No, I’m fine, thank you. They eat in silence. The evaluator observing.
Do the thing with the knife.
No...I’m not...no.
Come on!
It’s not a dinner thing. Silence.
It’s not an anytime thing.
What's the thing with the knife?
It’s hilarious.
No...it’s dumb. I have a small knife on my keychain. Which is only for adults. I do a thing with it sometimes...
You said I could get a knife.  137.
A jack-knife, yeah. When you're older.
Like ten.
No, like twenty.
Yeah. Charlie watches the evaluator’s face closely, trying to discern something, anything.
Charlie and Henry do his homework. Henry is sounding out word.
Dime, rime, lime, pime, sime--
Honey, stop guessing. You’re so close, stay with it.
(lying on his back) Ugh, I don’t want to do it.
What’s the first letter?
I don’t want to do it. Can I do the iPad?
No. Just look, what’s the first letter?
I don’t want to. It’s a T. What sound does T make.
(pause) Tuh.
Right and then just do the rest of it.  138.
Dime.
No! You have “Tuh” and “ime.” What is that? Henry takes a piece of tape and puts it on his mouth.
Time. It’s time. He looks at the evaluator. She nods. Henry rolls over onto his front, playing dead.
You’1l see, honey, one day it’s just going to click and you’1l be able to read everything.
(through the tape) I need a break. Can I play in my room?

Sure. Charlie tries to kiss him on lips. Henry gives him his head. Charlie kisses the top of his head. Henry runs out. Nancy is looking at the crack in the wall from Charlie’s punch. Charlie clocks this. Silence.
Do you ever observe married people?
No, why would I?
I was kidding.
Oh. Silence.
The knife thing is, I carry this knife on my keychain which his mother got me actually--  139. He takes out his key-ring and shows her the X-Acto knife.
--and I’d do this thing for his mom-- He clicks open the knife.
Where I pretend to cut myself, but I retract the blade-- He pantomimes cutting his arm.
But I don’t do it with him... The evaluator stares at Charlie with horror. Charlie hesitates and follows her gaze. Dark red blood streams down his arm.
Oh...that’s fine. It’s really bleeding. He covers it with his hand, the blood spreading between his fingers.
Are you OK?
(casually) Yeah, I must not have retracted the blade all the way.
Do you need-- Blood is getting over everything. He lowers the sleeve on his oxford shirt to cover the wound. Red blots immediatel soak through the cotton.
Yeah...yeah. No! I’m fine. (smiles at her and crosses his legs) What else can I tell you?
I think I have enough.
(again trying to talk casually) You got enough?  140.
(winces) Are you sure you’re OK?
Totally. I’m fine. Silence.
Well, I’1l leave you guys for tonight.
Oh, OK...

I‘1l be in touch if I have further questions. She stands and gathers her things while Charlie grabs her coat from a chair and holds it out to her, his left shirt arm growing crimson. She takes it, trying to avoid the blood.
Thanks. She climbs into her coat, Charlie nominally helping out with his good arm, and moves toward the door.
Thank you for the water.
Oh, yeah, sure.
You’re sure you’re OK?
(too loud) Yeah!
Bye bye.
Bye. She tries to open the door, but it’s locked. She turns a bolt and another latch but it still won’t open.  141.

Oh, let me-- Charlie rushes over and undoes the bolt. She tries to get out of the way of the blood, while he reaches his long ar around her to do this, putting them both in a strangely intimate proximity. He pulls and it won’t open.
I think you turned-- He does the latch and finally it opens.

Sorry. She flushes and smiles awkwardly and slips out, closing t door behind her. Charlie runs into the kitchen, swaying, leaning against t wall for support. His shirt is now soaked in blood. He rolls up his sleeve, and runs cold water on his arm. He winces. Watery blood fills up the pots and pans in the sink mixing with whatever bits of remaining food. He finds a small box of band-aids in the cupboard and ope about seven of them and tries to cover up the wound. But it’s still really bleeding. He wraps his arm in paper towels, sweat now sliding down his face and soaking his armpits. He drops to the kitchen floor and lies down on his back in exhaustion and pain. Two small bare feet step over him and pad over to the refrigerator.
Dad, are you OK?

Yeah, I’m just tired. Charlie rolls over onto his arm, hiding it from Henry. Th sound of milk being poured into a glass. Then the feet re approach and step back over Charlie. Little drips of milk whiten the floor.
(sleepily) Dad, did she like us?

(from the floor) Yeah, she thought we were great.  142. Fade to Black. INT. NICOLE’S NEW PLACE. ECHO PARK, LA. DAY Cassie, Sandra and Nicole sing “You Could Drive a Person Crazy” from the musical, Company -- The tight harmonies a sung a capella, and there are dance moves to go along wit it. The group of people watching includes kids and an agent, cast and crew from her show and family -- it’s a housewarming party. (The house looks very different from the home she shared with Charlie. More color, more patterns, more hippy-dippy more lamps, more her. It’s how she likes it.) They finish their song and everyone applauds, kind of to polite, but also because it was seriously, strangely grea INT. NICOLE’S KITCHEN. LATER Nora pops the cork on a big bottle of Cristal. Nicole is getting food together for the guests, pulling saran wrap off platters. She leaves cabinet doors open which she maneuvers around. Kids run through the room playing. Guests enter to grab drinks, etc.
I want your mom!
Oh really? Yeah-- Nora makes a heart symbol with her hands and leaps up on the kitchen counter, swinging her feet and drinking champagne like a teenager.
So, because Charlie dropped his claim to New York, we’re mostly done. Jay’s lost interest and Ted, his associate, is doing the paper work.
And we're not taking any money, right?  143.
We withdrew the claim for the MacArthur, which I think we could have gotten by the way, and they’re not asking for any of the show.
(clinking glasses) OK, good. Thank you for everything, Nora
You’re welcome, doll. (pause) And when Charlie’s in LA, I got the custody breakdown to be 55/45, so you'll have Henry one extra day every two weeks...
I thought we made it equal.
I tweaked it at the last minute. I just didn’t want him to be able to say he got 50/50.
But I don’t-- Bragging to his friends.
--want to do that.
Take it! You won.
(sadly) Uh huh. INT. NICOLE’S KITCHEN, LA. DAY CLOSE on Nicole writing her signature. She uses the last name (her maiden name) Ryder. Nicole sits at her kitchen table in LA.

He watches a mother and father with a young baby in the stroller.

.»..and the couch was technically hers pre-marriage, but, I mean, it was OUR couch, it’s not like I was going to BUY another couch but then when it comes time to split, it’s suddenly HER couch and I have no couch and-- I’m sitting on the floor is the short version. “Someone to hold you too close...” He gets up and walks to the piano. People know who he is, and are intrigued to see what he’s going to do. Sings “Being Alive” from Company. But Charlie remains in the threshold.
Hello? He hears laughter from the other rooms. And then Henry shouting excitedly.
Hello? Suddenly Carter runs, breathlessly, into the kitchen. He clutches a ray gun.
You’1l never take me! He sees Charlie and hesitates.
Hi. Sorry, the door was open. Carter puts his finger up to his lips.
Shhh.
Oh...OK.  146. The electronic sound of something bad happening. Carter’s been hit in laser tag. Sandra runs in holding a gun.
I got you! She hesitates when she sees Charlie.
Charlie, hi. She comes forward and hugs him. It isn’t cold particularly, but it isn’t what it was. Carter extends hi hand.
Carter.
Charlie.
Nicole’s still at work. Silence. Then Henry enters.
Hi.
Hi.

Can I get a hug? Henry hugs Charlie. Charlie smiles at everyone awkwardly. CUT TO: Charlie, Sandra and Carter talk at the dining roo table. Nicole arrives from filming her show. Carter rises, they kiss.
How'd it go?
Good. Donny’s dead now. I shot the scene where he merges with the ficus. Charlie grins.
She got an Emmy nomination!  147.
She’s a great actress.
No, for directing! Charlie nods, a bit stunned.
Congratulations.
I love it. Now I know what you were so obsessed with all the time. (moving) We should get ready! (to Charlie) We're the Beatles. Everyone clomps upstairs. Charlie follows.
I didn’t really get a costume together.
You can be George Martin.
I don’t need to be anything.
You got to be something-- At least a ghost! I'’11 get you a sheet-- Sandra and Carter hurry into different rooms, getting ready. Nicole enters into the bathroom.
We should leave soon! I’m saying that as much for me as anyone else.
I wanted to tell you, I took a residency at UCLA. I’m going to direct two plays in rep at Red Cat. Nicole reenters holding a sheet.
So, I’1l be here for a while.
That’s great. But something strikes her as sad about it too.
You OK?

Yeah. It’s only good. Sandra calls her for help with her costume. Nicole hands Charlie the sheet and goes into the next room. Charlie, alone, inspects the sheet. He notices the photos on the wall have been swapped out with different ones. He hears:

“Charlie is...in...cr...” -- something -- "neat and I re-ly on him to keep things in or-der. He’s energy con...” -- I don’t know what that word is -- Charlie drifts towards Henry’s room. Henry, legs dangling off his bed, reads from a crinkled loose leaf paper.
You’re getting so good at reading. (beat) What is that?
“He doesn’t look in the mirror too of-ten. He cries eas-ily in movies...” Charlie hesitates and sits next to Henry on the bed.
“He is very self-suf--”
Self-sufficient.
“--he can dar-n a sock--"  149.
That means sew, like a hole-- “--and cook himself dinner and ir--”
Break it into two parts.
Ur. On.
Not “ur” but “ire”
Ire. On.
Iron.

“--a shirt. He rarely gets def- eated (which I fell...feel like I al-ways do). Charlie takes all of my moods stead-ily, he doesn’t give in to them or make me feel bad about them. He’s a great dress-er, he never looks em--” I don’t know this one...
Embarrassing. Nicole appears in the doorway.
“--embarrassing wh-ich is hard for aman.” You read it now... He hands it to Charlie. Charlie reads:

“He loves being a dad, he loves all the things you’re supposed to hate, like the tantrums, the waking up at night-- He disappears into his own world. He and Henry are alike in that way. He can tell people they have food in their teeth or on their face in a way that doesn’t make them feel bad. Charlie is self-made -- his parents -- I only met them once -- but he told me there was-- (MORE )

(Charlie skips ahead for Henry's benefit) He’s brilliant at creating family out of whoever is around. With the theatre company he cast a spell that made everyone feel included. No one, not even an intern was unimportant.”
What’s an intern?
Like a helper. But who isn’t paid.
Why aren’t they paid?
They’re young. They’re learning... I don’t know, maybe if they do a good job, they get paid later?
OK. Keep going.

“He could remember all the inside jokes. He’s extremely organized and thorough. He’s very clear about what he wants unlike me who can’t always tell. I fell in love with him two seconds after I saw him and I’1l never stop loving him...” Charlie hesitates. He swallows. He’s crying.
“,..even though it doesn’t make sense anymore.”

(taken aback) It’s your night...

The boy wraps his arms around his Dad’s neck and Charlie lifts him.

I love you. She kisses Henry’s face which rests on Charlie’s shoulder and for a moment all three of their heads are nestled clo together. Then Nicole releases. Charlie, holding Henry, advances toward his parked car. Nicole watches.
